history.content:
Advice from Professor Sahai about CS 189:

"""189 is a "senior-level" course that is aimed solidly at the undergraduates in our department.

Undergraduates should look at Eta Kappa Nu's course map at: https://hkn.eecs.berkeley.edu/assets/course-map-2019-da79ecbe2fc25e6b6349b8931364890032b8d51aacaccea65151ae98316f0587.png to help understand where 189 sits in the context of the Berkeley EECS department's courses. 

As such, the expectation is a solid mastery of the entire lower-division, and especially the most relevant lower-division courses. For machine learning, those are unambiguously 16A and 16B, with a close secondary role being played by 70, a tertiary role played by Math 53, and a more distant tertiary role being played by 61B. This is not an entry-level upper-division course like 126 (probability) and 127 (optimization). Entry-level upper-division courses (sometimes referred to as "junior-level" courses) expect that students might not have yet completely mastered the relevant lower-division material, and so do a bit of review and take care to solidify the basics as they build forward. This course will not be doing so. We are basically going to assume that 126 and 127 have already done that job. Our goal is to help you learn machine learning.

Of course, machine learning as a discipline fundamentally uses the language of linear algebra and the machinery of optimization to get the job done, and it fundamentally uses models from probability to reflect strategically on what job it should be doing and what it should take to do that job. This is the nature of the subject. There is no avoiding that. We are not trying to teach you probability and optimization, but because of how we use probability and optimization, your appreciation and grounding for both of those foundational subjects is likely to improve through this course. That is normal --- well designed courses make you globally stronger. 

It is of course the same subject for graduate students as it is for undergraduates, and we understand that graduate students come to us from many departments. We expect you to have developed the appropriate mathematical maturity (including a grounding in linear algebra, vector calculus, basic optimization, and probability) through your own home discipline's foundational courses and your broader undergraduate education. This could be courses in statistical mechanics and quantum mechanics, in dynamics and control, or in a host of other subjects. There are lots of ways to learn the basics. For many graduate students at Berkeley, taking EECS 227A (which is cross listed with 127 the same way that 189 is cross listed with 289A) is really excellent preparation for taking this course, because the broader scope of optimization makes is easier for most grad students from diverse areas to connect to the foundations that we build upon here. If you're finding the basic linear algebra and modeling in HW0 to be challenging, graduate students are strongly encouraged to take 227A --- either instead of this course, or in addition. This depends on how much time your adviser is willing to let you dedicate to your ML quest this semester.

A pure math course like 110 on linear algebra is usually not enough. The reason is that the *modeling* dimension and what the linear-algebraic concepts *mean* physically or in terms of information is very important for machine learning. That dimension is what the freshman courses like 16AB emphasize for undergrads at Berkeley. For grad students from other applied fields, your own courses have presumably also helped you root your linear-algebraic concepts in physical intuition as well. Traditionally, grad students in pure math have also had to take breadth courses that have done the same. If you haven't had that grounding, then you'll have to work extra hard in this course, but your extreme facility with the technical manipulations will give you the space to do so. """
history.subject: CS 189

history.subject: CS 189
